text: Which part of a project excites you the most?

answers.text: Figuring out the most efficient algorithm to solve a complex problem.
Designing the user interface and making it look beautiful and feel intuitive.
Building the underlying structure, databases, and server-side logic.
Finding and fixing security vulnerabilities to protect the system.
Analyzing large datasets to find hidden patterns and insights.
Taking an idea from a concept and managing the team to build the final product.

text: What kind of problems do you enjoy solving?

answers.text: Abstract, mathematical, or physics-based puzzles.
Real-world, human-centric problems.
'How can we make this 10x faster or more efficient?'
'How can we prevent this from breaking or being attacked?'

text: Choose your ideal work environment:

answers.text: A fast-paced startup where I wear many hats.
A large, stable company with a well-defined role.
A research lab or academic setting.
Remote work, with flexible hours.
A collaborative, team-based office environment.

text: Which technology domain fascinates you the most?

answers.text: The Web (websites, web apps).
Mobile (smartphones, tablets).
The Cloud and Infrastructure (AWS, Azure, GCP).
Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning.
Hardware and the Internet of Things (IoT).
Blockchain and decentralized systems.
Augmented and Virtual Reality (AR/VR).

text: What's your preferred programming language or style?

answers.text: JavaScript/TypeScript for building interactive interfaces.
Python for data, scripting, and AI.
C++ for high-performance and system-level programming.
Java/C# for large-scale enterprise applications.
I prefer not to code, but to manage and guide.

text: How do you feel about public speaking or writing?

answers.text: I love it! I enjoy explaining complex topics to others.
I'm comfortable with it, especially for technical audiences.
I prefer to let my code speak for itself.
I enjoy writing documentation and guides.

text: What's more important in a final product?

answers.text: A flawless, secure, and highly reliable system.
A beautiful, intuitive, and delightful user experience.
A system that is incredibly fast and efficient.
A product that perfectly meets the business goals.

text: You discover a major bug in production. What's your first instinct?

answers.text: Figure out how to fix it immediately.
Investigate how this could have been prevented.
Communicate clearly with all stakeholders about the impact.
Write a detailed test case to ensure it never happens again.

text: Which of these sounds like the most fun side project?

answers.text: Building a smart home device with a Raspberry Pi.
Creating a blog to teach a complex topic.
Contributing to a major open-source project like Kubernetes.
Developing a simple 2D game from scratch.
Analyzing public datasets to find interesting trends.

text: How do you approach learning a new technology?

answers.text: I dive right in and start building something with it.
I read the official documentation from start to finish.
I find a good online course or tutorial to follow.
I look for research papers and academic articles on it.

text: What is your primary career motivator?

answers.text: High earning potential and financial stability.
Making a positive social or ethical impact.
Constantly learning and working on cutting-edge tech.
Achieving a healthy work-life balance.
Leading a team and mentoring others.

text: You are given a vague, high-level requirement. What do you do?

answers.text: Break it down into smaller, concrete technical tasks.
Ask a lot of questions to understand the user's true needs.
Start designing a high-level system architecture.
Prototype a few different solutions quickly.

text: Which of these tasks sounds the least appealing?

answers.text: Debugging a complex memory leak in C++ code.
Manually testing a web form for 2 hours.
Writing a 20-page project proposal.
Configuring firewall rules and network settings.

text: How important is it for you to understand the 'business' side of tech?

answers.text: It's critical. Tech only exists to serve a business purpose.
It's important, but my main focus is on the technology itself.
I prefer to focus purely on the technical challenges.
I enjoy connecting technology solutions to business outcomes.

text: What kind of data are you most interested in?

answers.text: User behavior and clickstream data.
Financial transactions and market data.
Images, video, and audio.
System logs and performance metrics.
Text and natural language.

text: Which role best describes your ideal position on a team?

answers.text: The visionary who sets the technical direction.
The expert who solves the hardest technical problems.
The mentor who helps everyone else grow.
The diplomat who connects the tech team to the business.

text: How do you feel about working with physical hardware?

answers.text: I love it! Building and tinkering with physical devices is fun.
I'm interested, but I prefer to focus on the software side.
I prefer to work entirely in software and the cloud.
I'm fascinated by the physics behind how hardware works.

text: What does 'innovation' mean to you in tech?

answers.text: Creating entirely new platforms like blockchain or the metaverse.
Finding a new algorithm that is 100x more efficient.
Improving a process to make developers 10x more productive.
Designing a product that changes how people live their lives.

text: Choose a field outside of traditional software that interests you:

answers.text: Finance and quantitative trading.
Medicine and biotechnology.
Architecture and construction.
Philosophy and ethics.

text: How do you prefer to manage your tasks?

answers.text: A well-defined list of tasks with clear priorities.
A flexible backlog where I can pick what to work on.
I prefer to define my own tasks based on high-level goals.
I thrive when I'm putting out fires and responding to issues.

text: What aspect of a system's lifecycle are you most passionate about?

answers.text: The initial design and architecture phase.
The core implementation and coding phase.
The testing, deployment, and maintenance phase.
The decommissioning and migration to a new system.

text: Finally, what do you want your legacy to be?

answers.text: I built a system that millions of people use and love.
I built a system that is incredibly robust and has never had a major outage.
I mentored the next generation of great engineers.
I solved a problem that people thought was impossible.
